claim_text: Climate change is causing global temperatures to rise at an unprecedented rate.
The Earth's average surface temperature has increased by approximately 1.1 degrees Celsius since the late 19th century.
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) reports that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary drivers of this warming trend.
Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have reached 420 parts per million, which is the highest level in over 3 million years.
Melting ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are contributing to rising sea levels.
Projections suggest oceans could rise by up to 1 meter by 2100.
Extreme weather events, including hurricanes, droughts, and heatwaves, have become more frequent and intense.
The Amazon rainforest has lost approximately 17% of its tree cover in the past 50 years due to deforestation.
Renewable energy sources like solar and wind power now account for over 30% of electricity generation in several European countries.
Climate change is expected to cause food shortages affecting hundreds of millions of people by 2050.
The Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, preferably to 1.5 degrees, compared to pre-industrial levels.
